references: Findley, J. S., A. H. Harris, D. E. Wilson, and C. Jones. 1975. Mammals of New Mexico. University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico. 360 pages.
Arnold, L. W. 1942. Notes on the life history of the sand pocket mouse. Journal of Mammalology 23:339-341.
Hall, Raymond E. 1946. Mammals of Nevada University of California Press, Berkely and Los Angeles, California.
Zeiner, D. C., et al., editors. 1990. California's wildlife. Vol. II. Mammals. California Dept. Fish & Game, Sacramento. xi + 407 pp.
Hall, E. R. 1995. Mammals of Nevada. University of Nevada Press: Las Vegas, Nevada. 710 pp.
Mantooth, S.J. and T.L. Best. 2005. Chaetodipus pencillatus. Mammalian Species No. 767: 1-3.
Cahalane, V.H. 1939. Mammals of the Chiracahua Mountains, Cochise County, Arizon. Journal of Mammalogy 20: 418-440.
Rosenzweig, M.L. and J. Winakur.. 1969. Population ecology of desert rodent communities: habitats and environmental complexity.. Ecology 50: 558-572..
Reynolds, H.G. and H.S. Haskell.. 1949. Life history notes on Price and Bailey pocket mice of southern Arizona.. Journal of Mammalogy 30: 150-156..
Hoffmeister, D.F. 1986. Mammals of Arizona. University of Arizona Press. The University of Arizona Press and the Arizona Game and Fish Department, Tucson, Arizona. 602 pages.
habitat_description:
Southwest:
In Arizona, this species is found in a variety of vegetation types; almost always where the vegetation is sparse (Hoffmeister 1986). Rosenzweig and Winakur (1969) suggest this species requires an upper-storey growth “undoubtedly depends on some such measure of bushy or shrubby growth.” These two are conflicting reviews on structure. Because both researchers are well-respected, structure will not be considered. This mouse is seemingly most abundant in, and confined to, the Lower Sonoran Zone (Cahalane 1939). In the Animas Mountains, New Mexico, this species occurs in association with mesquite and/ or other shrubs (Findley et al. 1975).  In Nevada, this species is confined to the Lower Sonoran Life Zone (Hall 1946). In the Sonoran Desert, C. penicillatus is one of the most abundant pocket mouse species and shows a strong affinity for creosotebush and saltbush (Mantooth and Best 2005).
In California, this species occurs in 3 disjunct populations: in Death Valley National Monument, southeastern Kern and northeastern Los Angeles cos. east to central San Bernardino Co.,
and in the southeast corner of the state from central Riverside Co. east to the Colorado River
and south to the border of Mexico. Locally common resident of desert habitats including
desert wash, desert succulent shrub, desert scrub, and alkali desert scrub. Elevational range
from below sea level (Death Valley) to 820 m (2700 ft)(quoted directly from Brylski et al. [CAWHR 2005] based on Zeiner et al. 1990). The desert pocket mouse excavates burrows and caches seeds within gravelly, silty, and sandy soils beneath shrubs, foraging on forbs, grasses, and shrubs (Arnold 1942, Reynolds and Haskell 1949).
